Usually a crossed circle. 1762 ImGuiMouseCursor_COUNT 1763 }; 1764 1765 // Enumeration for AddMouseSourceEvent() actual source of Mouse Input data. 1766 // Historically we use "Mouse" terminology everywhere to indicate pointer data, e.g. MousePos, IsMousePressed(), io.AddMousePosEvent() 1767 // But that "Mouse" data can come from different source which occasionally may be useful for application to know about. 1768 // You can submit a change of pointer type using io.AddMouseSourceEvent(). 1769 enum ImGuiMouseSource : int 1770 { 1771 ImGuiMouseSource_Mouse = 0, // Input is coming from an actual mouse. 1772 ImGuiMouseSource_TouchScreen, // Input is coming from a touch screen (no hovering prior to initial press, less precise initial press aiming, dual-axis wheeling possible). 1773 ImGuiMouseSource_Pen, // Input is coming from a pressure/magnetic pen (often used in conjunction with high-sampling rates). 1774 ImGuiMouseSource_COUNT 1775 }; 1776 1777 // Enumeration for ImGui::SetNextWindow***(), SetWindow***(), SetNextItem***() functions 1778 // Represent a condition. 1779 // Important: Treat as a regular enum! Do NOT combine multiple values using binary operators! All the functions above treat 0 as a shortcut to ImGuiCond_Always. 1780 enum ImGuiCond_ 1781 { 1782 ImGuiCond_None = 0, // No condition (always set the variable), same as _Always 1783 ImGuiCond_Always = 1 << 0, // No condition (always set the variable), same as _None 1784 ImGuiCond_Once = 1 << 1, // Set the variable once per runtime session (only the first call will succeed) 1785 ImGuiCond_FirstUseEver = 1 << 2, // Set the variable if the object/window has no persistently saved data (no entry in .ini file) 1786 ImGuiCond_Appearing = 1 << 3, // Set the variable if the object/window is appearing after being hidden/inactive (or the first time) 1787 }; 1788 1789 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1790 // [SECTION] Tables API flags and structures (ImGuiTableFlags, ImGuiTableColumnFlags, ImGuiTableRowFlags, ImGuiTableBgTarget, ImGuiTableSortSpecs, ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs) 1791 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1792 1793 // Flags for ImGui::BeginTable() 1794 // - Important! Sizing policies have complex and subtle side effects, much more so than you would expect. 1795 // Read comments/demos carefully + experiment with live demos to get acquainted with them. 1796 // - The DEFAULT sizing policies are: 1797 // - Default to ImGuiTableFlags_SizingFixedFit if ScrollX is on, or if host window has ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysAutoResize. 1798 // - Default to ImGuiTableFlags_SizingStretchSame if ScrollX is off. 1799 // - When ScrollX is off: 1800 // - Table defaults to ImGuiTableFlags_SizingStretchSame -> all Columns defaults to ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthStretch with same weight. 1801 // - Columns sizing policy allowed: Stretch (default), Fixed/Auto. 1802 // - Fixed Columns (if any) will generally obtain their requested width (unless the table cannot fit them all). 1803 // - Stretch Columns will share the remaining width according to their respective weight. 1804 // - Mixed Fixed/Stretch columns is possible but has various side-effects on resizing behaviors. 1805 // The typical use of mixing sizing policies is: any number of LEADING Fixed columns, followed by one or two TRAILING Stretch columns. 1806 // (this is because the visible order of columns have subtle but necessary effects on how they react to manual resizing). 1807 // - When ScrollX is on: 1808 // - Table defaults to ImGuiTableFlags_SizingFixedFit -> all Columns defaults to ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthFixed 1809 // - Columns sizing policy allowed: Fixed/Auto mostly. 1810 // - Fixed Columns can be enlarged as needed. Table will show a horizontal scrollbar if needed. 1811 // - When using auto-resizing (non-resizable) fixed columns, querying the content width to use item right-alignment e.g. SetNextItemWidth(-FLT_MIN) doesn't make sense, would create a feedback loop. 1812 // - Using Stretch columns OFTEN DOES NOT MAKE SENSE if ScrollX is on, UNLESS you have specified a value for 'inner_width' in BeginTable(). 1813 // If you specify a value for 'inner_width' then effectively the scrolling space is known and Stretch or mixed Fixed/Stretch columns become meaningful again. 1814 // - Read on documentation at the top of imgui_tables.cpp for details. 1815 enum ImGuiTableFlags_ 1816 { 1817 // Features 1818 ImGuiTableFlags_None = 0, 1819 ImGuiTableFlags_Resizable = 1 << 0, // Enable resizing columns. 1820 ImGuiTableFlags_Reorderable = 1 << 1, // Enable reordering columns in header row (need calling TableSetupColumn() + TableHeadersRow() to display headers) 1821 ImGuiTableFlags_Hideable = 1 << 2, // Enable hiding/disabling columns in context menu. 1822 ImGuiTableFlags_Sortable = 1 << 3, // Enable sorting. Call TableGetSortSpecs() to obtain sort specs. Also see ImGuiTableFlags_SortMulti and ImGuiTableFlags_SortTristate. 1823 ImGuiTableFlags_NoSavedSettings = 1 << 4, // Disable persisting columns order, width and sort settings in the .ini file. 1824 ImGuiTableFlags_ContextMenuInBody = 1 << 5, // Right-click on columns body/contents will display table context menu. By default it is available in TableHeadersRow(). 1825 // Decorations 1826 ImGuiTableFlags_RowBg = 1 << 6, // Set each RowBg color with ImGuiCol_TableRowBg or ImGuiCol_TableRowBgAlt (equivalent of calling TableSetBgColor with ImGuiTableBgFlags_RowBg0 on each row manually) 1827 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInnerH = 1 << 7, // Draw horizontal borders between rows. 1828 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuterH = 1 << 8, // Draw horizontal borders at the top and bottom. 1829 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInnerV = 1 << 9, // Draw vertical borders between columns. 1830 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuterV = 1 << 10, // Draw vertical borders on the left and right sides. 1831 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersH = ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInnerH | ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuterH, // Draw horizontal borders. 1832 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersV = ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInnerV | ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuterV, // Draw vertical borders. 1833 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInner = ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInnerV | ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInnerH, // Draw inner borders. 1834 ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuter = ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuterV | ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuterH, // Draw outer borders. 1835 ImGuiTableFlags_Borders = ImGuiTableFlags_BordersInner | ImGuiTableFlags_BordersOuter, // Draw all borders. 1836 ImGuiTableFlags_NoBordersInBody = 1 << 11, // [ALPHA] Disable vertical borders in columns Body (borders will always appear in Headers). -> May move to style 1837 ImGuiTableFlags_NoBordersInBodyUntilResize = 1 << 12, // [ALPHA] Disable vertical borders in columns Body until hovered for resize (borders will always appear in Headers). -> May move to style 1838 // Sizing Policy (read above for defaults) 1839 ImGuiTableFlags_SizingFixedFit = 1 << 13, // Columns default to _WidthFixed or _WidthAuto (if resizable or not resizable), matching contents width. 1840 ImGuiTableFlags_SizingFixedSame = 2 << 13, // Columns default to _WidthFixed or _WidthAuto (if resizable or not resizable), matching the maximum contents width of all columns. Implicitly enable ImGuiTableFlags_NoKeepColumnsVisible. 1841 ImGuiTableFlags_SizingStretchProp = 3 << 13, // Columns default to _WidthStretch with default weights proportional to each columns contents widths. 1842 ImGuiTableFlags_SizingStretchSame = 4 << 13, // Columns default to _WidthStretch with default weights all equal, unless overridden by TableSetupColumn(). 1843 // Sizing Extra Options 1844 ImGuiTableFlags_NoHostExtendX = 1 << 16, // Make outer width auto-fit to columns, overriding outer_size.x value. Only available when ScrollX/ScrollY are disabled and Stretch columns are not used. 1845 ImGuiTableFlags_NoHostExtendY = 1 << 17, // Make outer height stop exactly at outer_size.y (prevent auto-extending table past the limit). Only available when ScrollX/ScrollY are disabled. Data below the limit will be clipped and not visible. 1846 ImGuiTableFlags_NoKeepColumnsVisible = 1 << 18, // Disable keeping column always minimally visible when ScrollX is off and table gets too small. Not recommended if columns are resizable. 1847 ImGuiTableFlags_PreciseWidths = 1 << 19, // Disable distributing remainder width to stretched columns (width allocation on a 100-wide table with 3 columns: Without this flag: 33,33,34. With this flag: 33,33,33). With larger number of columns, resizing will appear to be less smooth. 1848 // Clipping 1849 ImGuiTableFlags_NoClip = 1 << 20, // Disable clipping rectangle for every individual columns (reduce draw command count, items will be able to overflow into other columns). Generally incompatible with TableSetupScrollFreeze(). 1850 // Padding 1851 ImGuiTableFlags_PadOuterX = 1 << 21, // Default if BordersOuterV is on. Enable outermost padding. Generally desirable if you have headers. 1852 ImGuiTableFlags_NoPadOuterX = 1 << 22, // Default if BordersOuterV is off. Disable outermost padding. 1853 ImGuiTableFlags_NoPadInnerX = 1 << 23, // Disable inner padding between columns (double inner padding if BordersOuterV is on, single inner padding if BordersOuterV is off). 1854 // Scrolling 1855 ImGuiTableFlags_ScrollX = 1 << 24, // Enable horizontal scrolling. Require 'outer_size' parameter of BeginTable() to specify the container size. Changes default sizing policy. Because this creates a child window, ScrollY is currently generally recommended when using ScrollX. 1856 ImGuiTableFlags_ScrollY = 1 << 25, // Enable vertical scrolling. Require 'outer_size' parameter of BeginTable() to specify the container size. 1857 // Sorting 1858 ImGuiTableFlags_SortMulti = 1 << 26, // Hold shift when clicking headers to sort on multiple column. TableGetSortSpecs() may return specs where (SpecsCount > 1). 1859 ImGuiTableFlags_SortTristate = 1 << 27, // Allow no sorting, disable default sorting. TableGetSortSpecs() may return specs where (SpecsCount == 0). 1860 // Miscellaneous 1861 ImGuiTableFlags_HighlightHoveredColumn = 1 << 28, // Highlight column headers when hovered (may evolve into a fuller highlight) 1862 1863 // [Internal] Combinations and masks 1864 ImGuiTableFlags_SizingMask_ = ImGuiTableFlags_SizingFixedFit | ImGuiTableFlags_SizingFixedSame | ImGuiTableFlags_SizingStretchProp | ImGuiTableFlags_SizingStretchSame, 1865 }; 1866 1867 // Flags for ImGui::TableSetupColumn() 1868 enum ImGuiTableColumnFlags_ 1869 { 1870 // Input configuration flags 1871 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_None = 0, 1872 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_Disabled = 1 << 0, // Overriding/master disable flag: hide column, won't show in context menu (unlike calling TableSetColumnEnabled() which manipulates the user accessible state) 1873 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_DefaultHide = 1 << 1, // Default as a hidden/disabled column. 1874 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_DefaultSort = 1 << 2, // Default as a sorting column. 1875 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthStretch = 1 << 3, // Column will stretch. Preferable with horizontal scrolling disabled (default if table sizing policy is _SizingStretchSame or _SizingStretchProp). 1876 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthFixed = 1 << 4, // Column will not stretch. Preferable with horizontal scrolling enabled (default if table sizing policy is _SizingFixedFit and table is resizable). 1877 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoResize = 1 << 5, // Disable manual resizing. 1878 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoReorder = 1 << 6, // Disable manual reordering this column, this will also prevent other columns from crossing over this column. 1879 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoHide = 1 << 7, // Disable ability to hide/disable this column. 1880 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoClip = 1 << 8, // Disable clipping for this column (all NoClip columns will render in a same draw command). 1881 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoSort = 1 << 9, // Disable ability to sort on this field (even if ImGuiTableFlags_Sortable is set on the table). 1882 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoSortAscending = 1 << 10, // Disable ability to sort in the ascending direction. 1883 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoSortDescending = 1 << 11, // Disable ability to sort in the descending direction. 1884 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoHeaderLabel = 1 << 12, // TableHeadersRow() will not submit horizontal label for this column. Convenient for some small columns. Name will still appear in context menu or in angled headers. 1885 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoHeaderWidth = 1 << 13, // Disable header text width contribution to automatic column width. 1886 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_PreferSortAscending = 1 << 14, // Make the initial sort direction Ascending when first sorting on this column (default). 1887 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_PreferSortDescending = 1 << 15, // Make the initial sort direction Descending when first sorting on this column. 1888 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IndentEnable = 1 << 16, // Use current Indent value when entering cell (default for column 0). 1889 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IndentDisable = 1 << 17, // Ignore current Indent value when entering cell (default for columns > 0). Indentation changes _within_ the cell will still be honored. 1890 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_AngledHeader = 1 << 18, // TableHeadersRow() will submit an angled header row for this column. Note this will add an extra row. 1891 1892 // Output status flags, read-only via TableGetColumnFlags() 1893 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsEnabled = 1 << 24, // Status: is enabled == not hidden by user/api (referred to as "Hide" in _DefaultHide and _NoHide) flags. 1894 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsVisible = 1 << 25, // Status: is visible == is enabled AND not clipped by scrolling. 1895 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsSorted = 1 << 26, // Status: is currently part of the sort specs 1896 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsHovered = 1 << 27, // Status: is hovered by mouse 1897 1898 // [Internal] Combinations and masks 1899 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthMask_ = ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthStretch | ImGuiTableColumnFlags_WidthFixed, 1900 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IndentMask_ = ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IndentEnable | ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IndentDisable, 1901 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_StatusMask_ = ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsEnabled | ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsVisible | ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsSorted | ImGuiTableColumnFlags_IsHovered, 1902 ImGuiTableColumnFlags_NoDirectResize_ = 1 << 30, // [Internal] Disable user resizing this column directly (it may however we resized indirectly from its left edge) 1903 }; 1904 1905 // Flags for ImGui::TableNextRow() 1906 enum ImGuiTableRowFlags_ 1907 { 1908 ImGuiTableRowFlags_None = 0, 1909 ImGuiTableRowFlags_Headers = 1 << 0, // Identify header row (set default background color + width of its contents accounted differently for auto column width) 1910 }; 1911 1912 // Enum for ImGui::TableSetBgColor() 1913 // Background colors are rendering in 3 layers: 1914 // - Layer 0: draw with RowBg0 color if set, otherwise draw with ColumnBg0 if set. 1915 // - Layer 1: draw with RowBg1 color if set, otherwise draw with ColumnBg1 if set. 1916 // - Layer 2: draw with CellBg color if set. 1917 // The purpose of the two row/columns layers is to let you decide if a background color change should override or blend with the existing color. 1918 // When using ImGuiTableFlags_RowBg on the table, each row has the RowBg0 color automatically set for odd/even rows. 1919 // If you set the color of RowBg0 target, your color will override the existing RowBg0 color. 1920 // If you set the color of RowBg1 or ColumnBg1 target, your color will blend over the RowBg0 color. 1921 enum ImGuiTableBgTarget_ 1922 { 1923 ImGuiTableBgTarget_None = 0, 1924 ImGuiTableBgTarget_RowBg0 = 1, // Set row background color 0 (generally used for background, automatically set when ImGuiTableFlags_RowBg is used) 1925 ImGuiTableBgTarget_RowBg1 = 2, // Set row background color 1 (generally used for selection marking) 1926 ImGuiTableBgTarget_CellBg = 3, // Set cell background color (top-most color) 1927 }; 1928 1929 // Sorting specifications for a table (often handling sort specs for a single column, occasionally more) 1930 // Obtained by calling TableGetSortSpecs(). 1931 // When 'SpecsDirty == true' you can sort your data. It will be true with sorting specs have changed since last call, or the first time. 1932 // Make sure to set 'SpecsDirty = false' after sorting, else you may wastefully sort your data every frame! 1933 struct ImGuiTableSortSpecs 1934 { 1935 const ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs* Specs; // Pointer to sort spec array. 1936 int SpecsCount; // Sort spec count. Most often 1. May be > 1 when ImGuiTableFlags_SortMulti is enabled. May be == 0 when ImGuiTableFlags_SortTristate is enabled. 1937 bool SpecsDirty; // Set to true when specs have changed since last time! Use this to sort again, then clear the flag. 1938 1939 ImGuiTableSortSpecs() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); } 1940 }; 1941 1942 // Sorting specification for one column of a table (sizeof == 12 bytes) 1943 struct ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs 1944 { 1945 ImGuiID ColumnUserID; // User id of the column (if specified by a TableSetupColumn() call) 1946 ImS16 ColumnIndex; // Index of the column 1947 ImS16 SortOrder; // Index within parent ImGuiTableSortSpecs (always stored in order starting from 0, tables sorted on a single criteria will always have a 0 here) 1948 ImGuiSortDirection SortDirection : 8; // ImGuiSortDirection_Ascending or ImGuiSortDirection_Descending 1949 1950 ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); } 1951 }; 1952 1953 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1954 // [SECTION] Helpers: Memory allocations macros, ImVector<> 1955 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1956 1957 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1958 // IM_MALLOC(), IM_FREE(), IM_NEW(), IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(), IM_DELETE() 1959 // We call C++ constructor on own allocated memory via the placement "new(ptr) Type()" syntax. 1960 // Defining a custom placement new() with a custom parameter allows us to bypass including <new> which on some platforms complains when user has disabled exceptions. 1961 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1962 1963 struct ImNewWrapper {}; 1964 inline void* operator new(size_t, ImNewWrapper, void* ptr) { return ptr; } 1965 inline void operator delete(void*, ImNewWrapper, void*) {} // This is only required so we can use the symmetrical new() 1966 #define IM_ALLOC(_SIZE) ImGui::MemAlloc(_SIZE) 1967 #define IM_FREE(_PTR) ImGui::MemFree(_PTR) 1968 #define IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(_PTR) new(ImNewWrapper(), _PTR) 1969 #define IM_NEW(_TYPE) new(ImNewWrapper(), ImGui::MemAlloc(sizeof(_TYPE))) _TYPE 1970 template<typename T> void IM_DELETE(T* p) { if (p) { p->~T(); ImGui::MemFree(p); } } 1971 1972 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1973 // ImVector<> 1974 // Lightweight std::vector<>-like class to avoid dragging dependencies (also, some implementations of STL with debug enabled are absurdly slow, we bypass it so our code runs fast in debug). 1975 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1976 // - You generally do NOT need to care or use this ever. But we need to make it available in imgui.h because some of our public structures are relying on it. 1977 // - We use std-like naming convention here, which is a little unusual for this codebase. 1978 // - Important: clear() frees memory, resize(0) keep the allocated buffer. We use resize(0) a lot to intentionally recycle allocated buffers across frames and amortize our costs. 1979 // - Important: our implementation does NOT call C++ constructors/destructors, we treat everything as raw data! This is intentional but be extra mindful of that, 1980 // Do NOT use this class as a std::vector replacement in your own code! Many of the structures used by dear imgui can be safely initialized by a zero-memset. 1981 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1982 1983 IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_OFF 1984 template<typename T> 1985 struct ImVector 1986 { 1987 int Size; 1988 int Capacity; 1989 T* Data; 1990 1991 // Provide standard typedefs but we don't use them ourselves. 1992 typedef T value_type; 1993 typedef value_type* iterator; 1994 typedef const value_type* const_iterator; 1995 1996 // Constructors, destructor 1997 inline ImVector() { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; } 1998 inline ImVector(const ImVector<T>& src) { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; operator=(src); } 1999 inline ImVector<T>& operator=(const ImVector<T>& src) { clear(); resize(src.Size); if (src.Data) memcpy(Data, src.Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(T)); return *this; } 2000 inline ~ImVector() { if (Data) IM_FREE(Data); } // Important: does not destruct anything 2001 2002 inline void clear() { if (Data) { Size = Capacity = 0; IM_FREE(Data); Data = NULL; } } // Important: does not destruct anything 2003 inline void clear_delete() { for (int n = 0; n < Size; n++) IM_DELETE(Data[n]); clear(); } // Important: never called automatically! always explicit. 2004 inline void clear_destruct() { for (int n = 0; n < Size; n++) Data[n].~T(); clear(); } // Important: never called automatically! always explicit. 2005 2006 inline bool empty() const { return Size == 0; } 2007 inline int size() const { return Size; } 2008 inline int size_in_bytes() const { return Size * (int)sizeof(T); } 2009 inline int max_size() const { return 0x7FFFFFFF / (int)sizeof(T); } 2010 inline int capacity() const { return Capacity; } 2011 inline T& operator[](int i) { IM_ASSERT(i >= 0 && i < Size); return Data[i]; } 2012 inline const T& operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(i >= 0 && i < Size); return Data[i]; } 2013 2014 inline T* begin() { return Data; } 2015 inline const T* begin() const { return Data; } 2016 inline T* end() { return Data + Size; } 2017 inline const T* end() const { return Data + Size; } 2018 inline T& front() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; } 2019 inline const T& front() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; } 2020 inline T& back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; } 2021 inline const T& back() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; } 2022 inline void swap(ImVector<T>& rhs) { int rhs_size = rhs.Size; rhs.Size = Size; Size = rhs_size; int rhs_cap = rhs.Capacity; rhs.Capacity = Capacity; Capacity = rhs_cap; T* rhs_data = rhs.Data; rhs.Data = Data; Data = rhs_data; } 2023 2024 inline int _grow_capacity(int sz) const { int new_capacity = Capacity ? (Capacity + Capacity / 2) : 8; return new_capacity > sz ? new_capacity : sz; } 2025 inline void resize(int new_size) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); Size = new_size; } 2026 inline void resize(int new_size, const T& v) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); if (new_size > Size) for (int n = Size; n < new_size; n++) memcpy(&Data[n], &v, sizeof(v)); Size = new_size; } 2027 inline void shrink(int new_size) { IM_ASSERT(new_size <= Size); Size = new_size; } // Resize a vector to a smaller size, guaranteed not to cause a reallocation 2028 inline void reserve(int new_capacity) { if (new_capacity <= Capacity) return; T* new_data = (T*)IM_ALLOC((size_t)new_capacity * sizeof(T)); if (Data) { memcpy(new_data, Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(T)); IM_FREE(Data); } Data = new_data; Capacity = new_capacity; } 2029 inline void reserve_discard(int new_capacity) { if (new_capacity <= Capacity) return; if (Data) IM_FREE(Data); Data = (T*)IM_ALLOC((size_t)new_capacity * sizeof(T)); Capacity = new_capacity; } 2030 2031 // NB: It is illegal to call push_back/push_front/insert with a reference pointing inside the ImVector data itself! e.g. v.push_back(v[10]) is forbidden. 2032 inline void push_back(const T& v) { if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); memcpy(&Data[Size], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; } 2033 inline void pop_back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); Size--; } 2034 inline void push_front(const T& v) { if (Size == 0) push_back(v); else insert(Data, v); } 2035 inline T* erase(const T* it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + 1, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - 1) * sizeof(T)); Size--; return Data + off; } 2036 inline T* erase(const T* it, const T* it_last){ IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size && it_last >= it && it_last <= Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t count = it_last - it; const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + count, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - (size_t)count) * sizeof(T)); Size -= (int)count; return Data + off; } 2037 inline T* erase_unsorted(const T* it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (it < Data + Size - 1) memcpy(Data + off, Data + Size - 1, sizeof(T)); Size--; return Data + off; } 2038 inline T* insert(const T* it, const T& v) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it <= Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); if (off < (int)Size) memmove(Data + off + 1, Data + off, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off) * sizeof(T)); memcpy(&Data[off], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; return Data + off; } 2039 inline bool contains(const T& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data++ == v) return true; return false; } 2040 inline T* find(const T& v) { T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data == v) break; else ++data; return data; } 2041 inline const T* find(const T& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data == v) break; else ++data; return data; } 2042 inline int find_index(const T& v) const { const T* data_end = Data + Size; const T* it = find(v); if (it == data_end) return -1; const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; return (int)off; } 2043 inline bool find_erase(const T& v) { const T* it = find(v); if (it < Data + Size) { erase(it); return true; } return false; } 2044 inline bool find_erase_unsorted(const T& v) { const T* it = find(v); if (it < Data + Size) { erase_unsorted(it); return true; } return false; } 2045 inline int index_from_ptr(const T* it) const { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; return (int)off; } 2046 }; 2047 IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_RESTORE 2048 2049 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2050 // [SECTION] ImGuiStyle 2051 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2052 // You may modify the ImGui::GetStyle() main instance during initialization and before NewFrame(). 2053 // During the frame, use ImGui::PushStyleVar(ImGuiStyleVar_XXXX)/PopStyleVar() to alter the main style values, 2054 // and ImGui::PushStyleColor(ImGuiCol_XXX)/PopStyleColor() for colors. 2055 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2056 2057 struct ImGuiStyle 2058 { 2059 float Alpha; // Global alpha applies to everything in Dear ImGui. 2060 float DisabledAlpha; // Additional alpha multiplier applied by BeginDisabled(). Multiply over current value of Alpha. 2061 ImVec2 WindowPadding; // Padding within a window. 2062 float WindowRounding; // Radius of window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows. Large values tend to lead to variety of artifacts and are not recommended. 2063 float WindowBorderSize; // Thickness of border around windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly). 2064 ImVec2 WindowMinSize; // Minimum window size. This is a global setting. If you want to constrain individual windows, use SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(). 2065 ImVec2 WindowTitleAlign; // Alignment for title bar text. Defaults to (0.0f,0.5f) for left-aligned,vertically centered. 2066 ImGuiDir WindowMenuButtonPosition; // Side of the collapsing/docking button in the title bar (None/Left/Right). Defaults to ImGuiDir_Left. 2067 float ChildRounding; // Radius of child window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows. 2068 float ChildBorderSize; // Thickness of border around child windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly). 2069 float PopupRounding; // Radius of popup window corners rounding. (Note that tooltip windows use WindowRounding) 2070 float PopupBorderSize; // Thickness of border around popup/tooltip windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly). 2071 ImVec2 FramePadding; // Padding within a framed rectangle (used by most widgets). 2072 float FrameRounding; // Radius of frame corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular frame (used by most widgets). 2073 float FrameBorderSize; // Thickness of border around frames. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly). 2074 ImVec2 ItemSpacing; // Horizontal and vertical spacing between widgets/lines. 2075 ImVec2 ItemInnerSpacing; // Horizontal and vertical spacing between within elements of a composed widget (e.g. a slider and its label). 2076 ImVec2 CellPadding; // Padding within a table cell. CellPadding.y may be altered between different rows. 2077 ImVec2 TouchExtraPadding; // Expand reactive bounding box for touch-based system where touch position is not accurate enough. Unfortunately we don't sort widgets so priority on overlap will always be given to the first widget. So don't grow this too much! 2078 float IndentSpacing; // Horizontal indentation when e.g. entering a tree node. Generally == (FontSize + FramePadding.x*2). 2079 float ColumnsMinSpacing; // Minimum horizontal spacing between two columns. Preferably > (FramePadding.x + 1). 2080 float ScrollbarSize; // Width of the vertical scrollbar, Height of the horizontal scrollbar. 2081 float ScrollbarRounding; // Radius of grab corners for scrollbar. 2082 float GrabMinSize; // Minimum width/height of a grab box for slider/scrollbar. 2083 float GrabRounding; // Radius of grabs corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular slider grabs. 2084 float LogSliderDeadzone; // The size in pixels of the dead-zone around zero on logarithmic sliders that cross zero. 2085 float TabRounding; // Radius of upper corners of a tab. You need to update 'BufTextLen' accordingly (0 <= BufTextLen < BufSize) and set 'BufDirty'' to true so InputText can update its internal state. 2366 ImWchar EventChar; // Character input // Read-write // [CharFilter] Replace character with another one, or set to zero to drop. return 1 is equivalent to setting EventChar=0; 2367 ImGuiKey EventKey; // Key pressed (Up/Down/TAB) // Read-only // [Completion,History] 2368 char* Buf; // Text buffer // Read-write // [Resize] Can replace pointer / [Completion,History,Always] Only write to pointed data, don't replace the actual pointer! 2369 int BufTextLen; // Text length (in bytes) // Read-write // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Exclude zero-terminator storage. In C land: == strlen(some_text), in C++ land: string.length() 2370 int BufSize; // Buffer size (in bytes) = capacity+1 // Read-only // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Include zero-terminator storage. In C land == ARRAYSIZE(my_char_array), in C++ land: string.capacity()+1 2371 bool BufDirty; // Set if you modify Buf/BufTextLen! // Write // [Completion,History,Always] 2372 int CursorPos; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always] 2373 int SelectionStart; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always] == to SelectionEnd when no selection) 2374 int SelectionEnd; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always] 2375 2376 // Helper functions for text manipulation. 2377 // Use those function to benefit from the CallbackResize behaviors. Calling those function reset the selection. 2378 IMGUI_API ImGuiInputTextCallbackData(); 2379 IMGUI_API void DeleteChars(int pos, int bytes_count); 2380 IMGUI_API void InsertChars(int pos, const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL); 2381 void SelectAll() { SelectionStart = 0; SelectionEnd = BufTextLen; } 2382 void ClearSelection() { SelectionStart = SelectionEnd = BufTextLen; } 2383 bool HasSelection() const { return SelectionStart != SelectionEnd; } 2384 }; 2385 2386 // Resizing callback data to apply custom constraint. As enabled by SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(). Callback is called during the next Begin(). 2387 // NB: For basic min/max size constraint on each axis you don't need to use the callback! The SetNextWindowSizeConstraints() parameters are enough. 2388 struct ImGuiSizeCallbackData 2389 { 2390 void* UserData; // Read-only. What user passed to SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(). Generally store an integer or float in here (need reinterpret_cast<>). 2391 ImVec2 Pos; // Read-only. Window position, for reference. 2392 ImVec2 CurrentSize; // Read-only. Current window size. 2393 ImVec2 DesiredSize; // Read-write. Desired size, based on user's mouse position. Write to this field to restrain resizing. 2394 }; 2395 2396 // [ALPHA] Rarely used / very advanced uses only. Use with SetNextWindowClass() and DockSpace() functions. 2397 // Important: the content of this class is still highly WIP and likely to change and be refactored 2398 // before we stabilize Docking features. Please be mindful if using this. 2399 // Provide hints: 2400 // - To the platform backend via altered viewport flags (enable/disable OS decoration, OS task bar icons, etc.) 2401 // - To the platform backend for OS level parent/child relationships of viewport. 2402 // - To the docking system for various options and filtering. 2403 struct ImGuiWindowClass 2404 { 2405 ImGuiID ClassId; // User data. 0 = Default class (unclassed). Windows of different classes cannot be docked with each others. 2406 ImGuiID ParentViewportId; // Hint for the platform backend. -1: use default. 0: request platform backend to not parent the platform. != 0: request platform backend to create a parent<>child relationship between the platform windows. Not conforming backends are free to e.g. parent every viewport to the main viewport or not. 2407 ImGuiID FocusRouteParentWindowId; // ID of parent window for shortcut focus route evaluation, e.g. Shortcut() call from Parent Window will succeed when this window is focused. 2408 ImGuiViewportFlags ViewportFlagsOverrideSet; // Viewport flags to set when a window of this class owns a viewport. This allows you to enforce OS decoration or task bar icon, override the defaults on a per-window basis. 2409 ImGuiViewportFlags ViewportFlagsOverrideClear; // Viewport flags to clear when a window of this class owns a viewport. This allows you to enforce OS decoration or task bar icon, override the defaults on a per-window basis. 2410 ImGuiTabItemFlags TabItemFlagsOverrideSet; // [EXPERIMENTAL] TabItem flags to set when a window of this class gets submitted into a dock node tab bar. May use with ImGuiTabItemFlags_Leading or ImGuiTabItemFlags_Trailing. 2411 ImGuiDockNodeFlags DockNodeFlagsOverrideSet; // [EXPERIMENTAL] Dock node flags to set when a window of this class is hosted by a dock node (it doesn't have to be selected!) 2412 bool DockingAlwaysTabBar; // Set to true to enforce single floating windows of this class always having their own docking node (equivalent of setting the global io.ConfigDockingAlwaysTabBar) 2413 bool DockingAllowUnclassed; // Set to true to allow windows of this class to be docked/merged with an unclassed window. // FIXME-DOCK: Move to DockNodeFlags override? 2414 2415 ImGuiWindowClass() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); ParentViewportId = (ImGuiID)-1; DockingAllowUnclassed = true; } 2416 }; 2417 2418 // Data payload for Drag and Drop operations: AcceptDragDropPayload(), GetDragDropPayload() 2419 struct ImGuiPayload 2420 { 2421 // Members 2422 void* Data; // Data (copied and owned by dear imgui) 2423 int DataSize; // Data size 2424 2425 // [Internal] 2426 ImGuiID SourceId; // Source item id 2427 ImGuiID SourceParentId; // Source parent id (if available) 2428 int DataFrameCount; // Data timestamp 2429 char DataType[32 + 1]; // Data type tag (short user-supplied string, 32 characters max) 2430 bool Preview; // Set when AcceptDragDropPayload() was called and mouse has been hovering the target item (nb: handle overlapping drag targets) 2431 bool Delivery; // Set when AcceptDragDropPayload() was called and mouse button is released over the target item. 2432 2433 ImGuiPayload() { Clear(); } 2434 void Clear() { SourceId = SourceParentId = 0; Data = NULL; DataSize = 0; memset(DataType, 0, sizeof(DataType)); DataFrameCount = -1; Preview = Delivery = false; } 2435 bool IsDataType(const char* type) const { return DataFrameCount != -1 && strcmp(type, DataType) == 0; } 2436 bool IsPreview() const { return Preview; } 2437 bool IsDelivery() const { return Delivery; } 2438 }; 2439 2440 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2441 // [SECTION] Helpers (ImGuiOnceUponAFrame, ImGuiTextFilter, ImGuiTextBuffer, ImGuiStorage, ImGuiListClipper, Math Operators, ImColor) 2442 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2443 2444 // Helper: Unicode defines 2445 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_INVALID 0xFFFD // Invalid Unicode code point (standard value). 2446 #ifdef IMGUI_USE_WCHAR32 2447 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0x10FFFF // Maximum Unicode code point supported by this build. 2448 #else 2449 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0xFFFF // Maximum Unicode code point supported by this build. 2450 #endif 2451 2452 // Helper: Execute a block of code at maximum once a frame. Convenient if you want to quickly create a UI within deep-nested code that runs multiple times every frame. 2453 // Usage: static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame oaf; if (oaf) ImGui::Text("This will be called only once per frame"); 2454 struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame 2455 { 2456 ImGuiOnceUponAFrame() { RefFrame = -1; } 2457 mutable int RefFrame; 2458 operator bool() const { int current_frame = ImGui::GetFrameCount(); if (RefFrame == current_frame) return false; RefFrame = current_frame; return true; } 2459 }; 2460 2461 // Helper: Parse and apply text filters. In format "aaaaa[,bbbb][,ccccc]" 2462 struct ImGuiTextFilter 2463 { 2464 IMGUI_API ImGuiTextFilter(const char* default_filter = ""); 2465 IMGUI_API bool Draw(const char* label = "Filter (inc,-exc)", float width = 0.0f); // Helper calling InputText+Build 2466 IMGUI_API bool PassFilter(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL) const; 2467 IMGUI_API void Build(); 2468 void Clear() { InputBuf[0] = 0; Build(); } 2469 bool IsActive() const { return !Filters.empty(); } 2470 2471 // [Internal] 2472 struct ImGuiTextRange 2473 { 2474 const char* b; 2475 const char* e; 2476 2477 ImGuiTextRange() { b = e = NULL; } 2478 ImGuiTextRange(const char* _b, const char* _e) { b = _b; e = _e; } 2479 bool empty() const { return b == e; } 2480 IMGUI_API void split(char separator, ImVector<ImGuiTextRange>* out) const; 2481 }; 2482 char InputBuf[256]; 2483 ImVector<ImGuiTextRange>Filters; 2484 int CountGrep; 2485 }; 2486 2487 // Helper: Growable text buffer for logging/accumulating text 2488 // (this could be called 'ImGuiTextBuilder' / 'ImGuiStringBuilder') 2489 struct ImGuiTextBuffer 2490 { 2491 ImVector<char> Buf; 2492 IMGUI_API static char EmptyString[1]; 2493 2494 ImGuiTextBuffer() { } 2495 inline char operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(Buf.Data != NULL); return Buf.Data[i]; } 2496 const char* begin() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.front() : EmptyString; } 2497 const char* end() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.back() : EmptyString; } // Buf is zero-terminated, so end() will point on the zero-terminator 2498 int size() const { return Buf.Size ? Buf.Size - 1 : 0; } 2499 bool empty() const { return Buf.Size <= 1; } 2500 void clear() { Buf.clear(); } 2501 void reserve(int capacity) { Buf.reserve(capacity); } 2502 const char* c_str() const { return Buf.Data ? Buf.Data : EmptyString; } 2503 IMGUI_API void append(const char* str, const char* str_end = NULL); 2504 IMGUI_API void appendf(const char* fmt, ...) IM_FMTARGS(2); 2505 IMGUI_API void appendfv(const char* fmt, va_list args) IM_FMTLIST(2); 2506 }; 2507 2508 // Helper: Key->Value storage 2509 // Typically you don't have to worry about this since a storage is held within each Window. 2510 // We use it to e.g. store collapse state for a tree (Int 0/1) 2511 // This is optimized for efficient lookup (dichotomy into a contiguous buffer) and rare insertion (typically tied to user interactions aka max once a frame) 2512 // You can use it as custom user storage for temporary values. Declare your own storage if, for example: 2513 // - You want to manipulate the open/close state of a particular sub-tree in your interface (tree node uses Int 0/1 to store their state). 2514 // - You want to store custom debug data easily without adding or editing structures in your code (probably not efficient, but convenient) 2515 // Types are NOT stored, so it is up to you to make sure your Key don't collide with different types. 2516 struct ImGuiStorage 2517 { 2518 // [Internal] 2519 struct ImGuiStoragePair 2520 { 2521 ImGuiID key; 2522 union { int val_i; float val_f; void* val_p; }; 2523 ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, int _val) { key = _key; val_i = _val; } 2524 ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, float _val) { key = _key; val_f = _val; } 2525 ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, void* _val) { key = _key; val_p = _val; } 2526 }; 2527 2528 ImVector<ImGuiStoragePair> Data; 2529 2530 // - Get***() functions find pair, never add/allocate. Pairs are sorted so a query is O(log N) 2531 // - Set***() functions find pair, insertion on demand if missing. 2532 // - Sorted insertion is costly, paid once. A typical frame shouldn't need to insert any new pair. 2533 void Clear() { Data.clear(); } 2534 IMGUI_API int GetInt(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0) const; 2535 IMGUI_API void SetInt(ImGuiID key, int val); 2536 IMGUI_API bool GetBool(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false) const; 2537 IMGUI_API void SetBool(ImGuiID key, bool val); 2538 IMGUI_API float GetFloat(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f) const; 2539 IMGUI_API void SetFloat(ImGuiID key, float val); 2540 IMGUI_API void* GetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key) const; // default_val is NULL 2541 IMGUI_API void SetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key, void* val); 2542 2543 // - Get***Ref() functions finds pair, insert on demand if missing, return pointer. Useful if you intend to do Get+Set. 2544 // - References are only valid until a new value is added to the storage. Calling a Set***() function or a Get***Ref() function invalidates the pointer. 2545 // - A typical use case where this is convenient for quick hacking (e.g. add storage during a live Edit&Continue session if you can't modify existing struct) 2546 // float* pvar = ImGui::GetFloatRef(key); ImGui::SliderFloat("var", pvar, 0, 100.0f); some_var += *pvar; 2547 IMGUI_API int* GetIntRef(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0); 2548 IMGUI_API bool* GetBoolRef(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false); 2549 IMGUI_API float* GetFloatRef(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f); 2550 IMGUI_API void** GetVoidPtrRef(ImGuiID key, void* default_val = NULL); 2551 2552 // Advanced: for quicker full rebuild of a storage (instead of an incremental one), you may add all your contents and then sort once. 2553 IMGUI_API void BuildSortByKey(); 2554 // Obsolete: use on your own storage if you know only integer are being stored (open/close all tree nodes) 2555 IMGUI_API void SetAllInt(int val); 2556 }; 2557 2558 // Helper: Manually clip large list of items. 2559 // If you have lots evenly spaced items and you have random access to the list, you can perform coarse 2560 // clipping based on visibility to only submit items that are in view. 2561 // The clipper calculates the range of visible items and advance the cursor to compensate for the non-visible items we have skipped. 2562 // (Dear ImGui already clip items based on their bounds but: it needs to first layout the item to do so, and generally 2563 // fetching/submitting your own data incurs additional cost. Coarse clipping using ImGuiListClipper allows you to easily 2564 // scale using lists with tens of thousands of items without a problem) 2565 // Usage: 2566 // ImGuiListClipper clipper; 2567 // clipper.Begin(1000); // We have 1000 elements, evenly spaced. 2568 // while (clipper.Step()) 2569 // for (int i = clipper.DisplayStart; i < clipper.DisplayEnd; i++) 2570 // ImGui::Text("line number %d", i); 2571 // Generally what happens is: 2572 // - Clipper lets you process the first element (DisplayStart = 0, DisplayEnd = 1) regardless of it being visible or not. 2573 // - User code submit that one element. 2574 // - Clipper can measure the height of the first element 2575 // - Clipper calculate the actual range of elements to display based on the current clipping rectangle, position the cursor before the first visible element. 2576 // - User code submit visible elements. 2577 // - The clipper also handles various subtleties related to keyboard/gamepad navigation, wrapping etc. 2578 struct ImGuiListClipper 2579 { 2580 ImGuiContext* Ctx; // Parent UI context 2581 int DisplayStart; // First item to display, updated by each call to Step() 2582 int DisplayEnd; // End of items to display (exclusive) 2583 int ItemsCount; // [Internal] Number of items 2584 float ItemsHeight; // [Internal] Height of item after a first step and item submission can calculate it 2585 float StartPosY; // [Internal] Cursor position at the time of Begin() or after table frozen rows are all processed 2586 void* TempData; // [Internal] Internal data 2587 2588 // items_count: Use INT_MAX if you don't know how many items you have (in which case the cursor won't be advanced in the final step) 2589 // items_height: Use -1.0f to be calculated automatically on first step. Otherwise pass in the distance between your items, typically GetTextLineHeightWithSpacing() or GetFrameHeightWithSpacing(). 2590 IMGUI_API ImGuiListClipper(); 2591 IMGUI_API ~ImGuiListClipper(); 2592 IMGUI_API void Begin(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f); 2593 IMGUI_API void End(); // Automatically called on the last call of Step() that returns false. 2594 IMGUI_API bool Step(); // Call until it returns false. The DisplayStart/DisplayEnd fields will be set and you can process/draw those items. 2595 2596 // Call IncludeItemByIndex() or IncludeItemsByIndex() *BEFORE* first call to Step() if you need a range of items to not be clipped, regardless of their visibility. 2597 // (Due to alignment / padding of certain items it is possible that an extra item may be included on either end of the display range). 2598 inline void IncludeItemByIndex(int item_index) { IncludeItemsByIndex(item_index, item_index + 1); } 2599 IMGUI_API void IncludeItemsByIndex(int item_begin, int item_end); // item_end is exclusive e.g. use (42, 42+1) to make item 42 never clipped. 2600 2601 #ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS 2602 inline void IncludeRangeByIndices(int item_begin, int item_end) { IncludeItemsByIndex(item_begin, item_end); } // [renamed in 1.89.9] 2603 inline void ForceDisplayRangeByIndices(int item_begin, int item_end) { IncludeItemsByIndex(item_begin, item_end); } // [renamed in 1.89.6] 2604 //inline ImGuiListClipper(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f) { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); ItemsCount = -1; Begin(items_count, items_height); } // [removed in 1.79] 2605 #endif 2606 }; 2607 2608 // Helpers: ImVec2/ImVec4 operators 2609 // - It is important that we are keeping those disabled by default so they don't leak in user space. 2610 // - This is in order to allow user enabling implicit cast operators between ImVec2/ImVec4 and their own types (using IM_VEC2_CLASS_EXTRA in imconfig.h) 2611 // - You can use '#define IMGUI_DEFINE_MATH_OPERATORS' to import our operators, provided as a courtesy. 2612 #ifdef IMGUI_DEFINE_MATH_OPERATORS 2613 #define IMGUI_DEFINE_MATH_OPERATORS_IMPLEMENTED 2614 IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_OFF 2615 static inline ImVec2 operator*(const ImVec2& lhs, const float rhs) { return ImVec2(lhs.x * rhs, lhs.y * rhs); } 2616 static inline ImVec2 operator/(const ImVec2& lhs, const float rhs) { return ImVec2(lhs.x / rhs, lhs.y / rhs); } 2617 static inline ImVec2 operator+(const ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { return ImVec2(lhs.x + rhs.x, lhs.y + rhs.y); } 2618 static inline ImVec2 operator-(const ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { return ImVec2(lhs.x - rhs.x, lhs.y - rhs.y); } 2619 static inline ImVec2 operator*(const ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { return ImVec2(lhs.x * rhs.x, lhs.y * rhs.y); } 2620 static inline ImVec2 operator/(const ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { return ImVec2(lhs.x / rhs.x, lhs.y / rhs.y); } 2621 static inline ImVec2 operator-(const ImVec2& lhs) { return ImVec2(-lhs.x, -lhs.y); } 2622 static inline ImVec2& operator*=(ImVec2& lhs, const float rhs) { lhs.x *= rhs; lhs.y *= rhs; return lhs; } 2623 static inline ImVec2& operator/=(ImVec2& lhs, const float rhs) { lhs.x /= rhs; lhs.y /= rhs; return lhs; } 2624 static inline ImVec2& operator+=(ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { lhs.x += rhs.x; lhs.y += rhs.y; return lhs; } 2625 static inline ImVec2& operator-=(ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { lhs.x -= rhs.x; lhs.y -= rhs.y; return lhs; } 2626 static inline ImVec2& operator*=(ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { lhs.x *= rhs.x; lhs.y *= rhs.y; return lhs; } 2627 static inline ImVec2& operator/=(ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { lhs.x /= rhs.x; lhs.y /= rhs.y; return lhs; } 2628 static inline bool operator==(const ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { return lhs.x == rhs.x && lhs.y == rhs.y; } 2629 static inline bool operator!=(const ImVec2& lhs, const ImVec2& rhs) { return lhs.x != rhs.x || lhs.y != rhs.y; } 2630 static inline ImVec4 operator+(const ImVec4& lhs, const ImVec4& rhs) { return ImVec4(lhs.x + rhs.x, lhs.y + rhs.y, lhs.z + rhs.z, lhs.w + rhs.w); } 2631 static inline ImVec4 operator-(const ImVec4& lhs, const ImVec4& rhs) { return ImVec4(lhs.x - rhs.x, lhs.y - rhs.y, lhs.z - rhs.z, lhs.w - rhs.w); } 2632 static inline ImVec4 operator*(const ImVec4& lhs, const ImVec4& rhs) { return ImVec4(lhs.x * rhs.x, lhs.y * rhs.y, lhs.z * rhs.z, lhs.w * rhs.w); } 2633 static inline bool operator==(const ImVec4& lhs, const ImVec4& rhs) { return lhs.x == rhs.x && lhs.y == rhs.y && lhs.z == rhs.z && lhs.w == rhs.w; } 2634 static inline bool operator!=(const ImVec4& lhs, const ImVec4& rhs) { return lhs.x != rhs.x || lhs.y != rhs.y || lhs.z != rhs.z || lhs.w != rhs.w; } 2635 IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_RESTORE 2636 #endif 2637 2638 // Helpers macros to generate 32-bit encoded colors 2639 // User can declare their own format by #defining the 5 _SHIFT/_MASK macros in their imconfig file. 2640 #ifndef IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 2641 #ifdef IMGUI_USE_BGRA_PACKED_COLOR 2642 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 16 2643 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8 2644 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 0 2645 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24 2646 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000 2647 #else 2648 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 0 2649 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8 2650 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 16 2651 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24 2652 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000 2653 #endif 2654 #endif 2655 #define IM_COL32(R,G,B,A) (((ImU32)(A)<<IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(B)<<IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(G)<<IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(R)<<IM_COL32_R_SHIFT)) 2656 #define IM_COL32_WHITE IM_COL32(255,255,255,255) // Opaque white = 0xFFFFFFFF 2657 #define IM_COL32_BLACK IM_COL32(0,0,0,255) // Opaque black 2658 #define IM_COL32_BLACK_TRANS IM_COL32(0,0,0,0) // Transparent black = 0x00000000 2659 2660 // Helper: ImColor() implicitly converts colors to either ImU32 (packed 4x1 byte) or ImVec4 (4x1 float) 2661 // Prefer using IM_COL32() macros if you want a guaranteed compile-time ImU32 for usage with ImDrawList API. 2662 // **Avoid storing ImColor! Store either u32 of ImVec4. This is not a full-featured color class. MAY OBSOLETE. 2663 // **None of the ImGui API are using ImColor directly but you can use it as a convenience to pass colors in either ImU32 or ImVec4 formats. Explicitly cast to ImU32 or ImVec4 if needed. 2664 struct ImColor 2665 { 2666 ImVec4 Value; 2667 2668 constexpr ImColor() { } 2669 constexpr ImColor(float r, float g, float b, float a = 1.0f) : Value(r, g, b, a) { } 2670 constexpr ImColor(const ImVec4& col) : Value(col) {} 2671 constexpr ImColor(int r, int g, int b, int a = 255) : Value((float)r * (1.0f / 255.0f), (float)g * (1.0f / 255.0f), (float)b * (1.0f / 255.0f), (float)a* (1.0f / 255.0f)) {} 2672 constexpr ImColor(ImU32 rgba) : Value((float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_R_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * (1.0f / 255.0f), (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * (1.0f / 255.0f), (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * (1.0f / 255.0f), (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * (1.0f / 255.0f)) {} 2673 inline operator ImU32() const { return ImGui::ColorConvertFloat4ToU32(Value); } 2674 inline operator ImVec4() const { return Value; } 2675 2676 // FIXME-OBSOLETE: May need to obsolete/cleanup those helpers. 2677 inline void SetHSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f){ ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, Value.x, Value.y, Value.z); Value.w = a; } 2678 static ImColor HSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f) { float r, g, b; ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, r, g, b); return ImColor(r, g, b, a); } 2679 }; 2680 2681 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2682 // [SECTION] Drawing API (ImDrawCmd, ImDrawIdx, ImDrawVert, ImDrawChannel, ImDrawListSplitter, ImDrawListFlags, ImDrawList, ImDrawData) 2683 // Hold a series of drawing commands. The user provides a renderer for ImDrawData which essentially contains an array of ImDrawList. 2684 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2685 2686 // The maximum line width to bake anti-aliased textures for. Build atlas with ImFontAtlasFlags_NoBakedLines to disable baking. 2687 #ifndef IM_DRAWLIST_TEX_LINES_WIDTH_MAX 2688 #define IM_DRAWLIST_TEX_LINES_WIDTH_MAX (63) 2689 #endif 2690 2691 // ImDrawCallback: Draw callbacks for advanced uses [configurable type: override in imconfig.h] 2692 // NB: You most likely do NOT need to use draw callbacks just to create your own widget or customized UI rendering, 2693 // you can poke into the draw list for that! Draw callback may be useful for example to: 2694 // A) Change your GPU render state, 2695 // B) render a complex 3D scene inside a UI element without an intermediate texture/render target, etc. 2696 // The expected behavior from your rendering function is 'if (cmd.UserCallback != NULL) { cmd.UserCallback(parent_list, cmd); } else { RenderTriangles() }' 2697 // If you want to override the signature of ImDrawCallback, you can simply use e.g. '#define ImDrawCallback MyDrawCallback' (in imconfig.h) + update rendering backend accordingly. 2698 #ifndef ImDrawCallback 2699 typedef void (*ImDrawCallback)(const ImDrawList* parent_list, const ImDrawCmd* cmd); 2700 #endif 2701 2702 // Special Draw callback value to request renderer backend to reset the graphics/render state. 2703 // The renderer backend needs to handle this special value, otherwise it will crash trying to call a function at this address. 2704 // This is useful, for example, if you submitted callbacks which you know have altered the render state and you want it to be restored. 2705 // Render state is not reset by default because they are many perfectly useful way of altering render state (e.g. changing shader/blending settings before an Image call). 2706 #define ImDrawCallback_ResetRenderState (ImDrawCallback)(-8) 2707 2708 // Typically, 1 command = 1 GPU draw call (unless command is a callback) 2709 // - VtxOffset: When 'io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled, 2710 // this fields allow us to render meshes larger than 64K vertices while keeping 16-bit indices. 2711 // Backends made for <1.71. will typically ignore the VtxOffset fields. 2712 // - The ClipRect/TextureId/VtxOffset fields must be contiguous as we memcmp() them together (this is asserted for). 2713 struct ImDrawCmd 2714 { 2715 ImVec4 ClipRect; // 4*4 // Clipping rectangle (x1, y1, x2, y2). Subtract ImDrawData->DisplayPos to get clipping rectangle in "viewport" coordinates 2716 ImTextureID TextureId; // 4-8 // User-provided texture ID. Set by user in ImfontAtlas::SetTexID() for fonts or passed to Image*() functions. Ignore if never using images or multiple fonts atlas. 2717 unsigned int VtxOffset; // 4 // Start offset in vertex buffer. ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: always 0, otherwise may be >0 to support meshes larger than 64K vertices with 16-bit indices. 2718 unsigned int IdxOffset; // 4 // Start offset in index buffer. 2719 unsigned int ElemCount; // 4 // Number of indices (multiple of 3) to be rendered as triangles. Vertices are stored in the callee ImDrawList's vtx_buffer[] array, indices in idx_buffer[]. 2720 ImDrawCallback UserCallback; // 4-8 // If != NULL, call the function instead of rendering the vertices. clip_rect and texture_id will be set normally. 2721 void* UserCallbackData; // 4-8 // The draw callback code can access this. 2722 2723 ImDrawCmd() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); } // Also ensure our padding fields are zeroed 2724 2725 // Since 1.83: returns ImTextureID associated with this draw call. Feed your application strings/characters to it then call BuildRanges(). 3014 // This is essentially a tightly packed of vector of 64k booleans = 8KB storage. 3015 struct ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder 3016 { 3017 ImVector<ImU32> UsedChars; // Store 1-bit per Unicode code point (0=unused, 1=used) 3018 3019 ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder() { Clear(); } 3020 inline void Clear() { int size_in_bytes = (IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX + 1) / 8; UsedChars.resize(size_in_bytes / (int)sizeof(ImU32)); memset(UsedChars.Data, 0, (size_t)size_in_bytes); } 3021 inline bool GetBit(size_t n) const { int off = (int)(n >> 5); ImU32 mask = 1u << (n & 31); return (UsedChars[off] & mask) != 0; } // Get bit n in the array 3022 inline void SetBit(size_t n) { int off = (int)(n >> 5); ImU32 mask = 1u << (n & 31); UsedChars[off] |= mask; } // Set bit n in the array 3023 inline void AddChar(ImWchar c) { SetBit(c); } // Add character 3024 IMGUI_API void AddText(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL); // Add string (each character of the UTF-8 string are added) 3025 IMGUI_API void AddRanges(const ImWchar* ranges); // Add ranges, e.g. builder.AddRanges(ImFontAtlas::GetGlyphRangesDefault()) to force add all of ASCII/Latin+Ext 3026 IMGUI_API void BuildRanges(ImVector<ImWchar>* out_ranges); // Output new ranges 3027 }; 3028 3029 // See ImFontAtlas::AddCustomRectXXX functions. 3030 struct ImFontAtlasCustomRect 3031 { 3032 unsigned short Width, Height; // Input // Desired rectangle dimension 3033 unsigned short X, Y; // Output // Packed position in Atlas 3034 unsigned int GlyphID; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID < 0x110000) 3035 float GlyphAdvanceX; // Input // For custom font glyphs only: glyph xadvance 3036 ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // Input // For custom font glyphs only: glyph display offset 3037 ImFont* Font; // Input // For custom font glyphs only: target font 3038 ImFontAtlasCustomRect() { Width = Height = 0; X = Y = 0xFFFF; GlyphID = 0; GlyphAdvanceX = 0.0f; GlyphOffset = ImVec2(0, 0); Font = NULL; } 3039 bool IsPacked() const { return X != 0xFFFF; } 3040 }; 3041 3042 // Flags for ImFontAtlas build 3043 enum ImFontAtlasFlags_ 3044 { 3045 ImFontAtlasFlags_None = 0, 3046 ImFontAtlasFlags_NoPowerOfTwoHeight = 1 << 0, // Don't round the height to next power of two 3047 ImFontAtlasFlags_NoMouseCursors = 1 << 1, // Don't build software mouse cursors into the atlas (save a little texture memory) 3048 ImFontAtlasFlags_NoBakedLines = 1 << 2, // Don't build thick line textures into the atlas (save a little texture memory, allow support for point/nearest filtering). The AntiAliasedLinesUseTex features uses them, otherwise they will be rendered using polygons (more expensive for CPU/GPU). 3049 }; 3050 3051 // Load and rasterize multiple TTF/OTF fonts into a same texture. The font atlas will build a single texture holding: 3052 // - One or more fonts. 3053 // - Custom graphics data needed to render the shapes needed by Dear ImGui. 3054 // - Mouse cursor shapes for software cursor rendering (unless setting 'Flags |= ImFontAtlasFlags_NoMouseCursors' in the font atlas). 3055 // It is the user-code responsibility to setup/build the atlas, then upload the pixel data into a texture accessible by your graphics api. 3056 // - Optionally, call any of the AddFont*** functions. If you don't call any, the default font embedded in the code will be loaded for you. 3057 // - Call GetTexDataAsAlpha8() or GetTexDataAsRGBA32() to build and retrieve pixels data. 3058 // - Upload the pixels data into a texture within your graphics system (see imgui_impl_xxxx.cpp examples) 3059 // - Call SetTexID(my_tex_id); and pass the pointer/identifier to your texture in a format natural to your graphics API. 3060 // This value will be passed back to you during rendering to identify the texture. Read FAQ entry about ImTextureID for more details. 3061 // Common pitfalls: 3062 // - If you pass a 'glyph_ranges' array to AddFont*** functions, you need to make sure that your array persist up until the 3063 // atlas is build (when calling GetTexData*** or Build()). We only copy the pointer, not the data. 3064 // - Important: By default, AddFontFromMemoryTTF() takes ownership of the data. Even though we are not writing to it, we will free the pointer on destruction. 3065 // You can set font_cfg->FontDataOwnedByAtlas=false to keep ownership of your data and it won't be freed, 3066 // - Even though many functions are suffixed with "TTF", OTF data is supported just as well. 3067 // - This is an old API and it is currently awkward for those and various other reasons! We will address them in the future! 3068 struct ImFontAtlas 3069 { 3070 IMGUI_API ImFontAtlas(); 3071 IMGUI_API ~ImFontAtlas(); 3072 IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFont(const ImFontConfig* font_cfg); 3073 IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontDefault(const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL); 3074 IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromFileTTF(const char* filename, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); 3075 IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryTTF(void* font_data, int font_data_size, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // Note: Transfer ownership of 'ttf_data' to ImFontAtlas! Will be deleted after destruction of the atlas. Set font_cfg->FontDataOwnedByAtlas=false to keep ownership of your data and it won't be freed. 3076 IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryCompressedTTF(const void* compressed_font_data, int compressed_font_data_size, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // 'compressed_font_data' still owned by caller. Compress with binary_to_compressed_c.cpp. 3077 IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryCompressedBase85TTF(const char* compressed_font_data_base85, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // 'compressed_font_data_base85' still owned by caller. Compress with binary_to_compressed_c.cpp with -base85 parameter. 3078 IMGUI_API void ClearInputData(); // Clear input data (all ImFontConfig structures including sizes, TTF data, glyph ranges, etc.) = all the data used to build the texture and fonts. 3079 IMGUI_API void ClearTexData(); // Clear output texture data (CPU side). Saves RAM once the texture has been copied to graphics memory. 3080 IMGUI_API void ClearFonts(); // Clear output font data (glyphs storage, UV coordinates). 3081 IMGUI_API void Clear(); // Clear all input and output. 3082 3083 // Build atlas, retrieve pixel data. 3084 // User is in charge of copying the pixels into graphics memory (e.g. create a texture with your engine). Then store your texture handle with SetTexID(). 3085 // The pitch is always = Width * BytesPerPixels (1 or 4) 3086 // Building in RGBA32 format is provided for convenience and compatibility, but note that unless you manually manipulate or copy color data into 3087 // the texture (e.g. when using the AddCustomRect*** api), then the RGB pixels emitted will always be white (~75% of memory/bandwidth waste. 3088 IMGUI_API bool Build(); // Build pixels data. } // Bit ambiguous: used to detect when user didn't build texture but effectively we should check TexID != 0 except that would be backend dependent... 3092 void SetTexID(ImTextureID id) { TexID = id; } 3093 3094 //------------------------------------------- 3095 // Glyph Ranges 3096 //------------------------------------------- 3097 3098 // Helpers to retrieve list of common Unicode ranges (2 value per range, values are inclusive, zero-terminated list) 3099 // NB: Make sure that your string are UTF-8 and NOT in your local code page. 3100 // Read https://github.com/ocornut/imgui/blob/master/docs/FONTS.md/#about-utf-8-encoding for details. 3101 // NB: Consider using ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder to build glyph ranges from textual data. 3102 IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesDefault(); 3124 IMGUI_API int AddCustomRectFontGlyph(ImFont* font, ImWchar id, int width, int height, float advance_x, const ImVec2& offset = ImVec2(0, 0)); 3125 ImFontAtlasCustomRect* GetCustomRectByIndex(int index) { IM_ASSERT(index >= 0); Glyphs->AdvanceX in a directly indexable way (cache-friendly for CalcTextSize functions which only this this info, and are often bottleneck in large UI). 3176 float FallbackAdvanceX; // 4 // out // = FallbackGlyph->AdvanceX 3177 float FontSize; // 4 // in // // Height of characters/line, set during loading (don't change after loading) 3178 3179 // Members: Hot ~28/40 bytes (for CalcTextSize + render loop) 3180 ImVector<ImWchar> IndexLookup; // 12-16 // out // // Sparse. Bigger than 1 when merging multiple font sources into one ImFont. 3188 ImWchar FallbackChar; // 2 // out // = FFFD/'?' // Character used if a glyph isn't found. 3189 ImWchar EllipsisChar; // 2 // out // = '...'/'.'// Character used for ellipsis rendering. 3190 short EllipsisCharCount; // 1 // out // 1 or 3 3191 float EllipsisWidth; // 4 // out // Width 3192 float EllipsisCharStep; // 4 // out // Step between characters when EllipsisCount > 0 3193 bool DirtyLookupTables; // 1 // out // 3194 float Scale; // 4 // in // = 1.f // Base font scale, multiplied by the per-window font scale which you can adjust with SetWindowFontScale() 3195 float Ascent, Descent; // 4+4 // out // // Ascent: distance from top to bottom of e.g. 'A' [0..FontSize] 3196 int MetricsTotalSurface;// 4 // out // // Total surface in pixels to get an idea of the font rasterization/texture cost (not exact, we approximate the cost of padding between glyphs) 3197 ImU8 Used4kPagesMap[(IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX+1)/4096/8]; // 2 bytes if ImWchar=ImWchar16, 34 bytes if ImWchar==ImWchar32.
